reviewText:
The Yawhg is absolutely beautiful for what it is, and it's a lot of fun, however, I really can't recommend it. It feels like a demo, or the introduction to a larger game. The entire game plays out like the character creation for a game that never happens. You spend six weeks making decisions that shape and define your character, each one including a small flavor text choice that lets you deepen your character choices, and then, when it feels like the game should be starting for real, all you do is pick a profession and see how good your character is at that profession.

I wanted to be a part of this world, I wanted to take my character out, to play a game with them. Who doesn't want that? This game is maybe worth a dollar. I wont say that I feel cheated, because I truly savor and enjoy the narrative, and the very novelty of a cooperative choose your own adventure experience was just enough to make me feel like at least I had gotten something interesting and beautiful, if lacking, but I would not recommend this for every gamer.

Be very aware, this game is extremely content light, and there is no campaign. Once your character is created after six weeks of character creation choices, that's the end of it. I really crave more, and am very disappointed in how little is here.

reviewText:
For a more comprehensive review, please see my write-up at http://criticalindiegamer.com/2014/02/the-yawhg-review-pc/

What can I say? It is very, very good, but also a brief experience. With a few friends the tales you weave will cause fits of raucous laughter, but they will be short-lived. A play-through takes around 10-30 minutes, and the end phase offers no real-resolution.

A folk music style soundtrack interweaves the basic, but charming presentation of the game. Both are lovely, and compliment one another well.

The Yawhg puts me in a tough place because I really enjoyed it, but I question its worth at $10. I don't usually draw comparisons between price and longevity, but if I paid $10 I can't help thinking I would feel a little let down. There are multiple play-throughs here, but even by the second play you will be seeing the same situations again.

Buy it if you are looking for a fun, memorable experience to play with your friends, and don't mind the longevity issues.

reviewText:
This is a visual novel in the same style as Monster Loves You. The game involves choosing where to go each turn, then responding to the randomized event that happens there. The event and your response to it will have positive or negative effects on one or more of your character's stats, which in turn influence later events and the end of the game. It's sort of like a dating sim, except instead of trying to get the girl, you're trying to survive the apocalypse.

The music and the writing are top notch, which makes the game a joy to play through several times over. Events are randomized to give the game more replay value, but they also interconnect with each other in surprising and delightful ways, so you're likely to see something new even on your tenth time through the game. Each run only takes about ten minutes, so finishing it multiple times is more fun than frustrating.

Though enjoyable as a solitary experience, the game really shines when used as a party game. Grab a few friends and try to stave off The Yawhg together - or don't, and see if your character can fare better than the others after the apocalypse.

I played the Yawhg a couple of times, and I must say it is quite an amusing game. It's all pretty straight-forward: you and/or your friends each choose a character (you can also choose characters yourself and play the game on your own) and choose a location you wish to go to. Each location has a couple of options on actions you can perform, such as cutting wood, tending to patients, and yes, even getting drunk! But beware: each choice you make might positively or negatively affect your stats. After a couple of turns, the mysterious Yawhg happens and each person will have to choose a role which fits their character's stats best (or you can do the opposite, and watch the outcome!), after which you'll get to know whether your town survived, and -more importantly- how your characters pick up their life again afterwards.

The Yawhg is a funny little game which you can play with friends. The graphics are all really fitting and nice, the music is simple, yet suits the game and the absolute highlight of the game is the amount of choices you can make, and the randomnized events you'll encounter. However, the game is VERY short. Almost too short. And that, in my humble opinion, is the only thing where it falls short, for me personally. However, the replay value is very big.

Get it during a sale, or if you like experimental choice-heavy little games like this one.

All in all, 7/10

reviewText: It's a simple enough concept of a game.  Four people go about their lives for 6 weeks, visiting up to 8 locations and choosing one of two actions at the location they choose.  Each choice will provide a bonus to the character's stats, and there will be a secondary event.  After 6 weeks, the town will be destroyed and you choose a role in order to help rebuild.\n\nThat is the gameplay in its entirety.  The genius of the game comes from the varied events, how those events can lead to other events, and the beautiful resolution as you're told what your character does with his/her life.  Also, the music is well-thought out.  I think there's only three separate songs for the six weeks, and they all use the same theme with an increase in tension as The Yawhg approaches.  The final song, however, is amazing and I don't think I'll ever grow tired of hearing it.  Whether it's $5 or $10, I insist that you pick this up, sit down with some friends, and live life inside of The Yahwg.

reviewText:
The Yawhg is a seemingly quick game with not much to do on the surface, but first glances of this game would be wrong.

With a wonderful aesthetic, beautiful music and images, and a strong if loose narrative, The Yawhg is a beautiful and refreshing game you can pick up for 10-20 minutes at a time.

The characters do not have much of a personality on their own, instead you sort of put your own will upon them and their options and events open to them change depending on their stats and previous choices. Saying that, you can end up with vastly different characterizations even using the same two people over and over again. The game supports up to 4 characters working in the world at once, and can in fact even be treated as a hotseat multiplayer game.

The choices and tasks you do in the game have deep and lasting effects, completely changing which avenues are open to you while keeping all avenues of adventure open. The Yawhg presents a rich and satisfying game, beautiful in looks and story. Filled with melancholy and whimsy the Yawhg is suitable for anyone looking for a good time.

reviewText:
I've played The Yawhg twice on my own and twice with a friend and had a blast every time! It's a really simple concept: something bad's going to happen in six weeks, but you're not going to worry about that, there's hunting to do in the forest, patients to tend at the hospital, and malicious hedges to confront!
You play a minimum of two characters (up to four) playing with friends is as easy as passing the keyboard (or controller) back and forth. Gameplay is simple, you choose an area of the city that you want to spend your week at, and then you choose what you want to do at that location. For instance, at the palace, you can choose to do administration work or attend a ball. Each activity will raise different stats (physique, finesse, charm, mind, magic, wealth). Random events at each location will also raise or lower certain stats, often, you will be asked to make a choice during these events. Whether you pass or fail seems to depend on stats some of the time and on random rolls other times. The game mixes comedy and horror in a way that reminds me of Welcome to Night Vale with a pinch of Princess Maker 2 and the art style of Don't Starve or a Roald Dahl book. It's funny, dark, and at times very disturbing, and it frequently flip flops between funny and horrifying moments in the space of seconds (the endings are particularly prone to this).
Yes, The Yawhg is pretty short, a single playthrough can take anywhere from ten to twenty minutes (or longer if you're playing with friends) and you will be seeing repeat events quite often, but the game has a ton of different endings, and each playthrough tells a different story.
In short, if you like interactive fiction, a bit of comedy with your horror, or maybe you're just looking for something unique, The Yawhg is well worth the full price.

reviewText:
First things first.  I must issue an apology to Gone Home, for it is not the most overrated game of 2013.  That title belongs to The Yawhg.

I'll try and start by saying some nice things about it.  The art is lovely, and the music is appropriate and enjoyable.  Oh, and it doesn't overstay it's welcome.  It took me all of 12 minutes to finish my first playthrough.

And it's a good thing my following playthroughs also lasted 12 minutes each, because that allowed me to better understand just how mechanically shallow this game is.  You (and maybe some freinds) take control of two to four characters living in a villiage that's six full weeks away from being sacked by the titular Yawhg.  You spend each week engaged in one of 16 different activities at one of eight different locations.  These activities will reward the character with stat upgrades, followed by a Visual Novel style scenario with two choices that can either grant additional stat points or take points away.  The scenarios themselves vary from day, but aren't very deep or engaging.

Sadly, no matter what you do, the Yawhg will level your hometown, forcing the survivors to rebuild.  This is where your pre-Yawhg stat-building comes into effect.  Each player character now has to take a role in rebuilding the town, and their performance in the choosen role is dependant their stats and other pre-Yawhg actions.  A character who built up a large magic stat will perform wonderfully as a conjuror, while someone with an abundance of charm will make a natural leader.  After a brief epilogue, the game ends.

And that's it.  That is all 12 minutes.  The game justifies it's existance by billing itself as some sort of multiplayer party game, with four players taking turns at the hotseat.  There's some replayability to be had, since certain events are dependant on the outcomes of other player actions, but these rarely effect the outcome.  In fact, barely anything affects the outcome.  The Yawhg smashes things up no matter what you do, and all your efforts amount to is how soundly the rebuilding effort goes.  The Yawhg is a Multiplayer Visual Novel that lacks both the gameplay mechanics for a deep multiplayer experience and the emotionally charged story of a good Visual Novel.

2/10

Ok so, here's the thing. The Yawhg isn't a bad game, in fact the ideas behind the game and the execution are very sound. The problem is that this really shouldn't be a paid product. The Yawhg feels and plays like a free flash game, and ironicly is no where near as good as other Flash games of this type.

Unlike the interactive fiction games you find on Kongrigate The Yawhg isn't really a single player game, rather is basicly a digital Cards vs. Humanity type experience (i hope that makes sense). The Yawhg is turnbased, with each turn repersenting a week Players take turns selecting what they will do on any given week, after 7 weeks a great disaster (the titualr Yawhg) will befall the city and using the skills you've learned throughout the last 7 weeks will try to repair the town in the best way you can. the idea being that the event's pre-Yawhg will be so wacky that players will be able to laugh and have a good time and all the post-Yawhg stuff will be really sad and dramatic. In practice though it's horibly broken, the way the game is structured with it's stat system means that after about one playthrough you'll have no problem easily maxing out a stat to win at the end. This would be fine if the random events at the core of the game kept you guessing, but they don't. Not because there bad or anything but because there are so few of them. I bet that if you played the game with four players one you would see everything this game had to offer. So in other words the game has no replay value what so ever and in the end for a game that costs $10 that's unacceptable.

It may sound like The Yawhg is the worst thing ever but it's not. It clear that the developers put a lot more heart and soul into it then... other games *cough* Call of Duty *cough* and i would love to see a game like this with a lot more random events. But The Yawhg just feels unfinished, both as a regular video game and as the party based experience it WANT'S to be. Meaning i can't recomend playing 10 or even 1 dollers on The Yawhg, becing as it clearly shouldn't be a paid product.

Nice art though.

reviewText:
In two sentences: Only pick this game up at a *steep* discount, as the game is too short, and there are not enough unique scenarios to justify the price tag.  I finished four (4) complete playthroughs in under an hour and saw many repeats.

More detailed review (based on the singleplayer experience):

The Yawhg is not so much a choose-your-own-adventure story (there is very little narrative, and your characters are gamepieces - not people) as it is a short opportunity to build up a couple of characters' stats in a short time to fulfill the game's hidden requirements.  There are four characters from whom to choose, but the only difference among them seems to be the appearance - I didn't notice any difference in events or stats.  As a single player, the game will ask you to choose two to four characters to play, and your goal is to raise their stats (there are six stats: physique, finesse, etc.).

For each turn, you will send each character to a place on the map to do a task.  There are eight locations and two possible tasks at each, so sixteen tasks in total from which to choose each turn, but two characters cannot be at the same location at the same time.  Each task will raise or lower one or more of your stats, but the only way to know what a task will affect is through trial and error.  Most tasks will also trigger a short text-based event
date:
which may allow you to choose your character's response and further affect their stat gain/loss.  To be clear, as a fan of both visual novels and choose-your-own-adventure-type games, the game's systems are *not* the reason I am not recommending it.

The problem comes from the fact that the game only consists of six weeks (each turn is a whole week).  This means that you only have six opportunities to raise each character's stats before the Yawhg appears (off-screen) and wrecks the town (again, off-screen).  At that point, you are given a choice of roles for each character to take in the rebuilding process; again, there are no explanations or listed stat requirements, so you just kind of guess.  Finally, the game checks to see if your character's stats are high enough to meet its invisible requirements, and you get a couple of epilogue slides reflecting your characters' success/failure and their fates afterwards.

That's it.  Six turns, a guess, and an epilogue.  So, each playthrough is EXTREMELY short to begin with, and then there is the fact that although the game supposedly has something like 100-200 unique events (I'm not arguing that it doesn't), you will see a lot of repeats in each playthrough, so subsequent playthroughs are not as exciting.  When I first played the game, I did 3 full playthroughs: the first using 2 characters, the second using all 4, and the third using 3 just to be thorough.  All 3 playthroughs took me a combined *32 minutes*.  Thinking that maybe I missed something or was in a bad mood that day, I waited some time, then played it once more before posting this review.  Again, maybe 10 minutes, and I'm pretty sure that all but one of the events and the two ending cards were repeats.

To finish, I hate to post a negative review for anything, but I just can't recommend this game at its $10 asking price given the dirth of content.  If you can get it for <$5 and plan on playing with friends, by all means go ahead: the art is unique and interesting, the music is nice, and I like the general concept -- there's simply not enough here to keep a person busy for even a single hour (and again, this is from someone who enjoys text- and menu-based games).  Sorry. :(

reviewText:
Excellent casual cooperative role-playing game.

For this game, you can choose from 4 characters (you need at least two) who take turns each week for 6 weeks at 16 different jobs around the city. Each job comes with stat upgrades and varying events that are at their best when they relate to each other: something that happens to one character can have an effect on what happens to another character later. Generally, the outcome of an event depends on whether you made a choice that your current stats will support: physique, finesse, mind, charm, magic, and wealth. Then the Yawgh comes, then there's another round that determines if the group has won or lost the game, and then each character gets their own ending. The writing is really nice, surprising at times, and the music supports it well.

You can easily play this game on the couch with up to 4 players, just pass the controller/keyboard around (or connect more controllers), but of course you can also control all of the characters yourself. We did three quite enjoyable couch play-throughs on another account, and they took about half an hour each.

It is not difficult to win this game. We wanted to play it more than once because one time is clearly not enough to see all the different things that can happen, and to reach all of the endings would take many more. Events start to repeat at some point, noticably so on our third game, but since there are choices and stats involved, many consequences of known events are still unknown.

This is a good game.

reviewText:
Damian Sommer and Emily Carroll’s The Yawhg is easily the most beautiful piece of choose-your-own-adventure fiction ever published. Carroll’s indie comics superstardom is immensely deserved and her work here depicts a wonderfully colorful world with a sensitive fairy tale look, defined not only by the setting, but by the flourish of the visual interface and of her distinctive hand lettering. Sommer and Carroll’s writing is whimsical, amusing, and mysterious, all in good measure. Ryan Roth’s shifting soundtrack feels perfectly of this world without being overbearing. As a production, The Yawhg is an aesthetic triumph.

As a game, its success is tempered. The Yawhg tells a story that would have benefitted from more prose. Completing one cycle in the coming and going of the apocalyptic Yawhg event takes only a few minutes. The random events are interesting but never deep, always dropping a choice in your lap before you know it. Every encounter is succinct to a fault, eschewing any sort of satisfying narrative exploration for an exceedingly quick presentation. Some choices and events will affect future encounters for other members of your party in different areas of the world, which is quite impressive. Still, the number of possible events is not astoundingly numerous, and given the short length of each “run,” events may repeat themselves as early as the second playthrough, before they’ve even vacated your short-term memory.

Playing the game with other people does somewhat alleviate the problems I’ve mentioned. It’s a joy to actually play a choose-your-own-adventure that actually allows for multiple people. Seeing the consequences of certain events weave between characters controlled by different people leads to some wonderful reactions. Chatter will do a lot to lengthen each go-around. As a social game, it’s quite nice. However, hosting or attending the right party that wants to kill an hour playing something like The Yawhg is an uncommon occurrence at best. And when it comes down to it, I prefer to immerse myself in the twists and turns of a good narrative and the beauty of great visuals all by my lonesome.

For me, the pleasures of The Yawhg are few – too few for me to heartily recommend. It is not a bad game, but it is a game that caters to a group of people who often play games and experience art together. It’s just not a game for someone like me.

reviewText:
The Yawhg is one of the best games I played in 2014. It's a rather simple game, on it's face- you have between two and four characters. They have stats. You take them places to do stuff. Stuff raises or lowers their stats. There are eight locations to visit, and two things to do at each location. There are also scripted(but randomly chosen) events that may or may not happen at each place. For example, if you play Mr. Moss and go to the Arena and fight, you may encounter an ex-girlfriend who is dating one of the new fighters. If you handle the situation well, you get a boost in mind and charm. Every event is written impressively well (with a few minor typos here and there) and illustrated really well.

It's very easy to want to just dive in, play all four characters, and experience everything in a single run. I've done that twice nown and each time I feel like I missed out something. I recommend if you truly want to experience this game, play two characters at a time and really take your time with it. Contemplate your decisions, from both stat-centric and a roleplay-centric points of view.

In general, I highly recommend it. It's rare to me that a game shines in every aspect- concept, design, execution. 9.5/10. would buy again.

20 minutes, are about how long one would need to finish a playthrough of The Yawhg.

It's not going to rock your world-view or revolutionize RPG genre. But it's the most calming game I have played in a long long time: you are given 6 rounds of free will, in the forms of overworld map and discrete choices, and all you get in returns are artworks and narrations. This is interactive equivalent of a good bedtime novel.

No button smashing, puzzle solving or timer countdown. Just you and your simple decisions. For some it's not worth the 9.99 USD, for me, it distills the very core of my interests: game narrative and mechanics.

reviewText: This is a simply-designed game - hand-drawn graphics and handwritten text. Instead of yet another game that showers you with blocks of preformatted lines, this is an adventure, two of them. This has an enchantingly human story. reviewText:
A very good party game that's great for developing emergent stories - like the tale of a humble woodcutter who became known for punching fists until they broke, gave to charity, and fought crime, the story of a simple man who kept getting ♥♥♥♥ on by life and ended up giving much of his wealth to help his city before living out an entirely ordinary life, or the gadabout socialite who made a million friends and got absolutely nowhere at the end of her life, becoming a drunk instead of contributing to society.

It does NOT really work as a single player game, however.  You really need at least one other player for the game to truly take off, and it works best with a full set.  The joy comes out of everyone's choices and motivations and goals bouncing off everyone else's and providing contrast - puppetmastering everyone for some kind of optimal result just isn't that interesting.  Shame it's local multiplayer only, then, but given how complex netcode can be, it's understandable.

In short, get this game if you can drag at least one friend in to play with you in real life.  Otherwise, it's much more hit-or-miss.

reviewText:
This game is incredibly story-driven, yet the relative lack of gameplay doesn't take away from the experience. The player still has to think through difficult decisions, sometimes without a right answer to choose from, and the story varies every time it's played. You could make bad decisions early on that affect the whole playthrough, you could ignore your stats and end up with a useless character, or the game could just hate you and force you to fail. Any one of those can give you leeches.

Everyone hates the leeches, yet it can be the funniest occurence in the game.

I'm not going to spoil anything in this (Says he after warning of leeches), but you can fail, succeed or survive, all of which are based on decisions you make during the initial six weeks and after the Yawhg. You can control the outcome, but sometimes you have to take a chance, do something different, and see what happens.

WARNING: This game will either draw you in or make you hate it. I cannot, nor can anyone else, guarantee that you will enjoy it. It's one of those games. Consider yourself warned.

I have been anticipating Steam release since this game was launched last year. I very nearly bought it when it was made known that it probably wouldn't make it, but I waited and it arrived. Meanwhile, I have watched hours of gameplay. Yeah, it probably ruined a few of the surprises for me, but I don't mind. I still haven't seen close to all of the endings.

---


Basically: Get the game, but make sure to watch gameplay videos first. You may regret buying it without doing so first. It's just that kind of game.

reviewText:
What fascinates me about this game is that each event that happens to one of your characters has no/little inherent significance - the power of each event and the narrative as a whole is whatever the player reads into the sequence.

I've had a doctor character lose faith in herself after a failure lead to the deaths of multiple townsfolk, only to regain her confidence out of necessity when the town needs her. I've had a rich socialite who cares for nobody but himself spiral into a depression after seeing the horrors that the Yawhg results in. None of these narratives are explicit - I am able to give them their own stories based upon these modular events that the game is constructed from.

A strangely large amount of fun, and fascinating at that.

reviewText: If I had to sum the general feeling of The Yawhg up in one word, it would probably have to be “poignant”. On the surface it's a clever, succinct and skilfully woven series of actions, reactions and consequences. The art style is whimsical enough to temper the sometimes brooding prose and the music treads the line between contemplative and melancholic. It's funny and twisted and thoughtful, often all at the same time. For so brief a game, it really pulls you in.\n\nUpon nearing the finish you grow acutely aware of the weight of your actions, and the impact your decisions have had on the characters you’ve encountered. The desire to change the outcomes of your latest play-through will compel you to keep coming back. It’s a beautifully made and artfully executed “what if?” trap. For those still looking for the perfect outcome, something tells me there’s no such thing in The Yawhg. But then again, I guess that’s kind of the point?

reviewText:
A beautiful game in all regards. A simple concept - you make choices for characters that have various effects and determine the outcome of the game. A concept that could easily be poorly done, boring, uninspiring. But The Yawhg is none of those things. Each game session is short - about ten minutes - a length that feels right, yet also leaves you (me) wanting more. So I play it again, this time making different decisions. And then again. And again.
Were I to classify this game, it would be interactive fiction, or rather, interactive storytelling. Storytelling, to me, isn't as detached as 'fiction.' A storyteller is there, talking to you, weaving a story, involving you in a different way than fiction (and I mean reading fiction when I say fiction). Both inspire your imagination and involve you in the story, but one - to me - is more personal, one makes you feel more like you helped tell the story. Thus why I think interactive storytelling is more fitting.
The gameplay is sort of like ... simulation games that involve making a choice of what you do that week from various tasks, each one of them raising certaain stats . Princess Maker 2, Long Live the Queen, Spirited Heart -- games that have similar gameplay in that regard - but The Yawhg is not like any of those games in other respects. Just the mechanic of picking an activity that raises (or lowers sometimes) stats.
At the end of the game, depending on the events that happened, you find out what your choices ultilmately lead to. What consequences or benefits they had. And you're told about the effects on the individual characters as well.

That's a pretty rough descripton of the The Yawhg. Not because I described it poorly, but no decritption can convey the experience of this  game. I loved the art style and find it very fitting for the themes and story. I loved he writing, which this focusing on story telling, that's a good thing to love. Every aspect is equal in quality and the quality is outstanding. I'm stating this so it's clear I am not intending to say anyone is more responsible for The Yawhg being the work of art that it is. I love music. Music is key for me when it comes to developing atmosphere and evoking emotions. So with that in mind, the music of The Yawhg is so well done. I loved everything about the score (and the game, like I said, I'm music oriented, so think of this is being for all those people who thrive off music. I know people who thrive off writing in the same way I thrive off music,  and I can tell you every aspect of this game is in harmony and I hope if the deveopers were to read this, that it wouldn't come across as me downplaying all the oher aspects of the game. Super important to me, obviously, which is why I keep restating it.)
The song that plays during the end sequence is ... I can't imagine a song that would sound more fitting. It's a beautiful song and ...

All I can say is, if you like storytelling and interactive fiction/storytelling, and can enjoy a game that is short (but has a lot of replayability), I recommend this game with every recommending bone (it's a thing..) in my body. It's a work of art and everyone who worked on this -- I thank you for making this and giving it (releasing) to the world to experience and enjoy and  if all of you decide to colloborate again - I'll buy whatever you make. And I'll be watching out for projects in general that involve any of the developers/etc that worked on this game.

IN SHORT, I give this the highest recommendation I can.

The Yawhg is, let's be honest, an experiment in creating a multiplayer version of those raise-stat type story games.  This doesn't mean it's bad - it's quite good - but know what you're getting into when you buy it.  Basically it's a smart visual novel game for parties.

Two to four characters make choices, lead lives, and prepare as a strange threat - the Yawhg - approaches.  Doing things raises character stats and affects other elements of the game.  A magical experiment, a won gladiatorial event, an undifused bomb, all affect other characters.  When the disaster does happen, characters then choose their path after, which affects the end of the game.

Gameplay is pretty short - the game is meant to be replayed.  Graphics are decent, and the storybook look really works.  Music is great.

So the question on buying it is do you want an experimental multiplayer story game."  If you do
recommended: its not for you - but I consider it a good game."

reviewText:
Ultimately, this is a story generator - one with a fair bit of charm, at that.

Basics of gameplay involve choosing which of four people who play as (you are told to choose at least two, seems like a richer story to take all four however), and send them off to various places and to do various tasks each day, which results in boosts to various stats and an event.  What this event is will vary depending on where you are, what has happened to your character (or possibly other characters), and the outcome will depend on your stats.  Ultimately very simple concept, pleasantly and characterfully executed all throughout.  The game culminates with the arrival of the Yawhg, who brings ruin, and you then assign your characters to various tasks (which they, again, will do better or worse at depending on their skill proficiencies).

The goal is most certainly not to *win* the game - or, at least, that doesn't *need* to be your goal.  As stated, this is an exercise in story-telling, and you may not find the story served well by achieving the happiest possible outcome.  In spite of your efforts, surprise and sorrow may visit, all depending on various factors (which you may not foresee at the time, but make sense when you think of what your characters have done).

To the point, that is what it is.  And it's nice!

I really can't express well enough my love for this game, how good it is or how impressed I still am at its rejogability. I honestly never found a game focused on the story that had a level this high of rejogability and story based games are my favorite ones! I played this game dozens and dozens and dozens of times with my auntie, my cousin and my sister - sometimes other guests but mostly them - and I saw dozens and dozens and dozens of variations of events and endings to the point of thinking ocasionally that I finally had found everything that had to be found there but I always had the pleasant surprise of discovering that I was very mistaken. To this day, I still don't doubt that there things I didn't saw in that game even though I played it A LOT(my hours may indicate that).

The Yawgh is a mostly story based game but its drawings have a beautiful style with lovely colours and together with its soundtrack, they create the perfect atmosphere for the tale of the seven days of some townies before the Yawgh comes to destroy it.

Btw, there's NOTHING you can to stop the Yaghw of coming. This is one of the points in which the story starts to differ of the classical RPGs we all know. Your objective is to obtain points in certain habilities by going to places with random events during every week until everything is destroyed and you can finally put your talents in a good use(or not, there's a bad and a medium ending after all!).

Each event is written very well and there's A LOT of them and EVEN MORE variations of it according to not only your habilities but also some events that might happened during others players turns! The random events of this game sometimes get connections and form a little story line, which is freaking awesome. If you poisoned the water in week 02, there's a great chance that you and your friends will see some consequences of it in different locations during the rest of the game.
